abstract:
In this project, researchers are studying the impact of moist soil management activities on waterfowl populations and wetland habitats. They conduct annual waterfowl abundance counts at the TD-1 project site to monitor migration and response to improved habitat. At the TD-2 project area, they have added remote cameras to create 71 acres of hemi marsh habitat for local waterfowl production. However, due to tall vegetation and sedimentation, there is currently low waterfowl production in this area.

To address this issue, researchers place elevated camera traps across the TD-2 project area and take photos every hour from sunrise to sunset. Each camera trap covers a measurable surface area of one acre, allowing for density estimates across the entire project area. By analyzing these images, they can observe changes in waterfowl use as more habitat management occurs. This method is necessary to effectively monitor and evaluate the success of the moist soil management activities in creating suitable wetland habitats for waterfowl and other obligate species. It solves the issue of limited visibility and accessibility to remote areas, allowing researchers to collect valuable data on population trends and behavior over time.

```python

    # Simulate taking a photo and updating the waterfowl density estimate

    current_time += datetime.timedelta(hours=1)
    
# Run the hourly photo taking simulation for 365 hours (one year)
for i in range(365):
    take_photos()
```

This code does not directly relate to the actual research method, but it can be used as a simple illustration of how camera traps can capture hourly images and potentially update waterfowl density estimates.
description:
In this text, the authors discuss moisture management activities and their impact on wetland habitats for waterfowl and other obligate species. The study is being conducted at two separate projects, TD-1 and TD-2. At TD-1, researchers have been conducting waterfowl abundance counts for three consecutive years to monitor spring migration and the response of waterfowl to increased habitat management through moist soil management practices such as tillage, planting, mowing, flooding, and burning.

At TD-2, the project aimed to create 71 acres of hemi-marsh habitat for local waterfowl production. However, with tall emergent vegetation and sedimentation, current wetlands in TD-2 have seen very low amounts of waterfowl production. To witness the positive response in waterfowl use as more habitat management occurs, researchers added 2 remote cameras to the area during the 2020 camera survey season.

The study design involves biologists placing elevated camera traps across various habitats within each project area. Cameras capture photos every hour from sunrise to sunset, providing a total of 14 hours of data per day. Each camera trap has a measurable surface area (1 acre) to create sub-samples of density estimates across the entire project area. This approach allows for a comprehensive assessment of waterfowl populations and habitat usage within each project.
